awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Site-Differentiated Bimetallic Catalysts for Precise Polyolefin Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymers are one of the most widely used man-made materials today. Their applications range from common plastic bags to life-saving medical devices. Many methods currently used to make polymers are inefficient, energy intensive, and/or require expensive raw materials. To promote more sustainable manufacturing practices, Dr. Loi Do is developing new ways to create polymers directly from naturally occurring and readily available raw materials. The key to Dr. Do's technology is the use of new catalysts that control how the raw material building blocks are connected to form polymers. This research benefits society by providing new materials that can improve our quality of life. Dr. Do is also actively involved in outreach activities that integrate his interests in industrial chemistry at the University of Houston (UH). Dr. Do is creating programs that give high school and undergraduate students the opportunity to interact with professional scientists and learn about chemistry in everyday life. Dr. Do excites students about pursuing careers in STEM fields. Dr. Do is also engaging in hands-on laboratory training and mentoring of young chemists to prepare them to become the next generation of scientific leaders. 

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Do at the University of Houston (UH) is developing new sustainable routes to access technologically useful polyolefins. This research seeks to eliminate the need to use expensive alpha olefin co-monomers in the preparation of low- and medium-density polyethylene and to overcome the tendency of transition metal catalysts to be inhibited by polar vinyl olefins. Dr. Do's bimetallic catalysts take advantage of metal-metal cooperativity to achieve reactivity patterns that are distinct from those of conventional monometallic catalysts. These studies are being guided by mechanistic investigations using spectroscopic tools to interrogate the nature of observable reaction intermediates and computational methods to evaluate the energy barriers of discrete reaction steps. This work is critical to our understanding of olefin polymerization catalysis and may provide insights into where catalyst design improvements could be made. Dr. Do is also initiating educational outreach plans that will introduce young students to the chemical profession. The objectives of Dr. Do's educational activities are to make learning chemistry accessible to the general public and give chemistry majors at UH the practical skills that they need to be successful in their independent careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Polyolefins are the most widely used plastics in the world due to their low-cost and diverse applications. Because of their strong chemical bonds, they do not readily degrade in the environment and can contribute to plastics pollution at the end of their useful lifetime. To increase the sustainability of such materials, our strategy is to install polar groups and/or branch points along their polymer chains so that they could be more easily deconstructed while retaining their desirable properties. This goal necessitated the creation of molecular catalysts that would enable the synthesis of polyolefins with high precision and efficiency.

The intellectual merit of our work is the development of a new class of cation-responsive polymerization catalysts, which are species that can change reactivity based on the identity of the metal ions they are paired with. These catalysts are distinct from conventional catalysts because they can produce polymers with customized structures and compositions starting from the same catalyst platform. Our strategy takes advantage of the fact that different metal ions possess different characteristics and that their interactions with metal binding groups can be tuned. The research supported by this NSF CAREER grant resulted in 9 peer-reviewed publications, 1 issued patent (4 additional patents are pending), and the mentoring of numerous trainees (3 postdocs, 5 graduate students, 6 undergraduate students, and 2 high school students).

The broader impact of our work is the creation of new polymeric materials that may have useful applications in different industrial sectors (e.g., in sports equipment, construction material, packaging, etc.). During the NSF CAREER funding period, we also engaged in a variety of activities that expanded our network of academic and industrial chemists to enhance chemical education and training. For example, a seminar series focused on research conducted at primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) was established in the Department of Chemistry at the University of Houston (UH). Each year, 2-3 faculty members from Texas PUIs visited UH to present their work and shared best practices on teaching and mentoring. The PI also gave research presentations at several local chemical companies, which led to new collaborations and expanded job opportunities for UH students. The PI was also involved in chemical outreach activities, including participating in workshops at Minority Serving Institutions to talk to undergraduate students about applying to graduate schools and careers in chemistry.

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2024
Modified by: Loi Do
